description: From Middle English mackerell, macrell, macrelle, makarell, makerel, makerell, makerelle, makrel, makrell, makyrelle, from Old French maquerel. Further origin unknown.

nouns.description: mackerel (countable and uncountable, plural mackerel or mackerels)

definitionGroups.group: Certain smaller edible fish, principally true mackerel and Spanish mackerel in family Scombridae, often speckled,

entries.meaning: typically Scomber scombrus in the British isles.
examples: He sometimes pinches the maids till their arms are as many colours as a mackerel’s back.

entries.meaning: A true mackerel, any fish of tribe Scombrini (Scomber spp., Rastrelliger spp.)
Certain other similar small fish in families Carangidae, Gempylidae, and Hexagrammidae.

description: From Middle English makerel, maquerel, from Old French maquerel, from Middle Dutch makelare, makelaer (“broker”) (> makelaar (“broker, peddler”)). See also French maquereau.

examples: […]  nyghe his hows dwellyd a maquerel or bawde  […]
